abstract.p: In this paper we present an improved zero-power controlled magnetic suspension system that has the capability to adjust stiffness. The conventional zero-power control system produces constant negative stiffness, and the stiffness solely depends on the capacity of the permanent magnets or the gap–force coefficient of the magnets. This becomes an obstacle to the fields of application of zero-power control where the adjustment of stiffness is necessary, such as developing a vibration isolation system. In this research, the basic zero-power control system is modified such that it can adjust stiffness by adding a minor proportional feedback of displacement to the zero-power controller. Finally, a vibration isolation system is developed by combining a positive stiffness spring in series with a negative stiffness suspension realized by the modified zero-power controller. The proposed control system and the developed vibration isolation system are investigated both analytically and experimentally.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Vibration isolation offers a promising approach to protecting a precision instrument in the field of advanced manufacturing, such as producing computer microchips. In this paper, a vibration isolation system is investigated. There are two kinds of detrimental vibrations that may have an influence on the objective performances. The first is direct disturbance, a vibration caused by disturbance acting on the isolation table; and the other one is base disturbance or ground vibration, which is transmitted to the isolation table through the suspension. Both vibration disturbances can be suppressed either by using passive techniques or using active control. Vibration absorbers extract kinetic energy from the vibrating host system and the active system introduces opposing forces in the structure to affect compensation.

Passive vibration isolation of mechanical systems using a spring and damper is a widespread technique because of its low cost. However, passive techniques need the trade-off between the isolation elements where high stiffness suspension is used for suppressing direct disturbance and suspension with soft stiffness is used for ground vibration isolation (Rivin, 2003; Harris, 1996). On the other hand, active techniques do not havesuch limitations, and performances are better as well (Yoshioka et al., 2001; Benassi et al., 2004; Daley et al., 2006; Yasuda and Ikeda, 1993; Yasuda et al., 1996). Recently vibration isolation systems have been developed using active zero-power controlled magnetic suspension with the aim of reducing system development costs as well as maintenance costs (Mizuno, 2001; Hoque et al., 2006b). The above systems use a combined system with positive and negative springs in series. Amiddle mass is introduced into this system between the base and the isolation table. A positive stiffness spring is used between the base and the middle mass and a suspension with negative stiffness is used between the middle mass and the isolation table.

An active zero-power control is used to realize negative stiffness by using a hybrid magnet consisting of an electromagnet and permanent magnets. This control achieves the steady state in which the attractive force produced by the permanent magnets is balanced by the weight of the suspended object, and the control current converges to zero. Since there is no steady energy consumption for achieving stable levitation, it has been applied to space vehicles (Henrikson et al., 1974; Sabnis et al., 1975, Poubeau et al., 1977), to magnetically levitated carrier systems in clean rooms (Morishita et al., 1989) and to non-contact guide systems for elevator cars (Morishita and Akashi, 2001; Morishita and Seki, 2001).

A unique characteristic of the zero-power control is that it realizes negative stiffness (Mizuno and Takemori, 2002). Therefore, a very high (theoretically infinite) stiffness of a vibration isolation system can be achieved by combining a mechanical spring in series with a zero-power control. However, the amplitude of negative stiffness realized by zero-power control is solely dependent on magnetomotive force or the gap–force coefficient of the permanent magnets. The amplitude of negative stiffness is fixed for a particular magnet and the gap between the suspended object and the permanent magnet, the suspension system does not have any capability to change stiffness. Hence, realizing infinite stiffness by combining a mechanical positive spring with it is a very troublesome task, because many mechanical springs are needed to be used to adjust both stiffnesses. This isone obstacle to the development of a vibration isolation system using zero-power control. Moreover, it can be pointed out that realizing negative stiffness can also be generalized by using linear actuators such as a voice coil motor instead of a hybrid magnet (Mizuno et al., 2007a).

This paper offers an improved zero-power magnetic suspension system that has the capability to adjust stiffness. This modified zero-power control introduces a proportional feedback of displacement to the original zero-power controller. The characteristics of the modified control system design are discussed analytically. Finally, a vibration isolation system is developed by connecting a mechanical spring in series with the modified zero-power control. Some experimental results are presented to show the efficacy of the control system, as well as the vibration isolation system.

sec.title: 2. Realization of negative stiffness
sec.p: The negative stiffness can be generated by using active or passive techniques. In this research, the negative stiffness is generated by an actively controlled modified zero-power magnetic suspension. The zero-power control can be achieved by several techniques (Morishita andAzukizawa, 1988; Morishita and Akashi, 2001), and the modified zero-power controller can be derived from the fundamental zero-power control. The basic model, controller and the characteristics of the zero-power control system are briefly described in the following.

sec.title: 2.1. Fundamental model of a zero-power control system
sec.p:
A basic model of a magnetic suspension system using zero-power control is shown in Figure 1. The basic zero-power controller is designed for simplicity based on a linearized equation of motion of a magnetic suspension system. It is assumed that the displacement of the suspended mass is very small and the nonlinear terms are neglected. The suspended object with a mass of m is assumed to move only in the vertical translational direction. The equation of motion of the model is given by Figure 1.
Basic model of a zero-power control system.

where x is the displacement of the suspended object, ks is the gap–force coefficient of the permanent magnet, ki is the current–force coefficient of the electromagnet, i is the control current, and w is the disturbance acting on the suspended object. The coefficients ks and ki are positive. When each Laplace-transform variable is denoted by its capital, and the initial values are assumed to be zero for simplicity, the transfer function representation of the dynamics described by Equation (1) becomes (2)X(s)=1ms2-ks(kiI(s)+W(s))=1s2-a0(b0I(s)+d0W(s))
where a0=ks/m,b0=ki/m, and d0=1/m

sec.title: 2.2. Basic zero-power controlled negative stiffness
sec.p:
Zero power can be achieved either by feeding back the velocity of the suspended object or by introducing a minor feedback of the integral of current in the PD (proportional–derivative) control system (Mizuno and Takemori, 2002). Since PD control is a fundamental control law in the magnetic suspension, zero-power control is realized from PD control in this research using the second approach. In the current controlled magnetic suspension system, PD control can be represented as (3)I(s)=-(pd+pvs)X(s) where pd is the proportional feedback gain and pv is the derivative feedback gain. Figure 2 shows the block diagram of a current-controlled zero-power controller where a minor integral feedback of current is added to the PD control. Figure 2.
Block diagram of the zero-power controller.

The control current of the basic zero-power controller is given by (4)I(s)=-(pd+pvs)X(s)+pzsI(s) where pz is the integral feedback gain in the minor current loop. From Equations (2)–(4), it can be writtenas (5)X(s)W(s)=(s-pz)d0s3+(b0pv-pz)s2+(b0pd-a0)s+a0pz (6)I(s)W(s)=-s(spv+pd)d0s3+(b0pv-pz)s2+(b0pd-a0)s+a0pz
To estimate the stiffness for direct disturbance, the direct disturbance, W(s), on the isolation table is considered to be stepwise, that is (7)W(s)=F0s,(F0:constant)
From Equations (6) and (7) (8)limt→∞i(t)=lims→0sI(s)=0

This indicates that control current always converges to zero in the basic zero-power control for any load. The steady displacement of the suspension, from Equations (5) and (7), is given by (9)limt→∞x(t)=lims→0sX(s)=-d0a0F0=-F0ks

The negative sign in the right-hand side illustrates that the new equilibrium position is in the direction opposite to the applied force. It means that the system realizes negative stiffness. Assume that stiffness of any suspension is denoted by k. The stiffness of the zero-power controlled magnetic suspension is, therefore, negative and given by (10)k=-ks

sec.title: 2.3. Adjustment of stiffness by a modified zero-power controller
sec.p:
The stiffness realized by the basic zero-power control is constant, as shown in Equation (10). However, it is necessary to adjust stiffness of the zero-power control system in many applications, such as vibration isolation systems. There are two approaches to adjust stiffness of the zero-power control system. The first is by adding a minor displacement feedback to the zero-power control current, and the other is by adding a proportional feedback in the minor current feedback loop (Ishino et al., 2009). In this work, the stiffness variation capability of a zero-power control is realized using the first approach. Figure 3 shows the block diagram of the improved (modified) zero-power controller that is capable of adjusting stiffness. The control current of the modified zero-power controller is given by (11)Im(s)=-(pdss-pz+pvs2s-pz+ps)X(s) where ps is the proportional displacement feedback gain across the basic zero-power controller. Figure 3.
Block diagram of the modified zero-power controller that can adjust negative stiffness.

The transfer-function representation of the dynamics shown in Figure 3 is given by (12)X(s)W(s)=(s-pz)d0s3+(b0pv-pz)s2+(b0pd+b0ps-a0)s+(a0pz-b0pspz) (13)I(s)W(s)=-(pvs2+pds+pss-pspz)d0s3+(b0pv-pz)s2+(b0pd+b0ps-a0)s+(a0pz-b0pspz)
Therefore, the steady displacement for the modified control system becomes (14)limt→∞x(t)=lims→0sX(s)=-d0pza0pz-b0pspzF0=-F0ks-kips
Therefore, the stiffness of the modified zero-power control system becomes (15)k=-(ks-kips)=-ks '.
This indicates that the stiffness can be increased or decreased by changing the feedback gain ps.
Moreover, the control current for the modified system, from Equations (7) and (13), becomes (16)limt→∞i(t)=lims→0sI(s)=--d0pspza0pz-b0pspzF0=psks-kipsF0,≠0
for any non-zero ps.
Therefore, it can be mentioned from Equation (16) that the zero-power characteristics will be lost for the modified zero-power controller and a minor control current is necessary for the system.

sec.title: 3. Principle of vibration isolation
sec.p: The vibration isolation system is developed to generate infinite (high) stiffness for direct disturbing forces and to maintain low stiffness for floor vibration. Infinite stiffness can be realized by connecting a mechanical spring in series with a magnetic spring that has negative stiffness (Mizuno, 2001; Hoque et al., 2006b). When two springs with spring constants of k1 and k2 are connected in series, the total stiffness kc is given by (17)kc=k1k2k1+k2

The basic system represented by Equation (17) has been modified by introducing a secondary suspension to avoid some limitations for system design and supporting heavy payloads (Mizuno et al., 2006). The concept is demonstrated in Figure 4. A spring k3 is added in parallel with the serial connection of positive and negative springs. Hence, the total stiffness k~c is given by (18)k~c=k1k2k1+k2+k3 Figure 4.
Principle of vibration isolation system using negative stiffness.
However, if one of the springs has negative stiffness that satisfies (19)k1=-k2
the resultant stiffness becomes infinite for any finite value of k3, that is (20)|k~c|=∞
Therefore, the compliance of the isolation table to the base, κ can be written as (21)κ=1/k~c=0

This research applies this principle of generating infinite stiffness against direct disturbance to the system. On the other hand, if low stiffness of mechanical springs for system (k1, k3) are used, it can maintain good ground vibration isolation performance as well.

sec.title: 4. Modeling of the system
sec.p:
The mathematical modeling of the developed system and its analysis are briefly presented in this section. The model is based on Equation (18) as discussed in Section 3. The basic model of the vibration isolation system with a modified zero-power controller is shown in Figure 5. The system consists of a base, the middle mass, and an isolation table. The positive stiffness, k1, is used between the base and the middle mass, and the negative stiffness, k2, is realized between the middle mass and the isolation table. A passive weight support mechanism is introduced directly between the base and the isolation table. In this work, the negative stiffness, k2, is generated by the modified zero-power controller. Figure 5.
Basic model of the vibration isolation system.

sec.title: 4.1. Basic model of the system
sec.p: The mathematical model of the system is analyzed here. In this section, the high-order terms will be neglected for simplicity. The equations of motion of the model about the vertical translational motion of the isolation table, m2, and the middle mass, m1, can be written as (22)m1x··1=-k1(x1-x0)-c1(x·1-x·0)+ks(x1-x2)+kiim (23)m2x··2=-k3(x2-x0)-c3(x·2-x·0)-ks(x1-x2)-kiim+w where x0, x1, x2 are the displacements of the floor, the middle mass and the isolation table, k1 is the stiffness of the springs between the base and the middle mass, c1 is the damping constant between the base and the middle mass, ki is the current–force coefficient of the hybrid magnet between the middle mass and the isolation table, ks is the gap–force coefficient of the magnet, im is the control current in the modified zero-power controller, k3 is the stiffness of the weight support springs between the base and the isolation table, c3 is the damping constant between the base and the isolation table and w is the direct disturbance acting on the isolation table.

Hence, from Equation (11), the control current of the modified zero-power controller can be applied to the system represented by Equations (22) and (23) as (24)Im(s)=-(pdss-pz+pvs2s-pz+ps)(X1(s)-X2(s))

sec.title: 5. Experimental set up
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the single-axis vibration isolation system combining positive and negative stiffness suspension in series. It consisted of a circular base, a circular middle mass and a circular isolation table. The height, diameter and weight of the system were 300 mm, 200 mm and 20 kg, respectively. The positive stiffness in the lowerpart was realized by three mechanical springs and an electromagnet. The stiffness of each coil springs was 3.9 N/mm. The electromagnet coil had 180-turns and 1.3Ω resistance. The wire diameter of the coil was0.6 mm. The relative displacement of the base to middle mass was measured by an eddy-current displacement sensor. However, it can be mentioned that, permanent magnets can also be attached to the lowerelectromagnet to reduce coil current in the electromagnet. Figure 6.
Photograph of the vibration isolation system.

The negative stiffness suspension in the upper part was achieved by a hybrid magnet consisted of an electromagnet (180 turns) that was fixed to the middle mass and six permanent magnets (15 mm × 2 mm) attached tothe electromagnet target on the isolation table. Thepermanent magnets are made of neodymium–iron–boron (NdFeB). Another displacement sensor was used to measure the relative displacement between the middle mass and the isolation table. The isolation table was also supported by three coil springs as weight support mechanism, and the stiffness of each spring was 2.35 N/mm.

The motion of the isolation table and that of the middle mass were restricted to move only in the vertical direction. This was done by using a vertical shaft which was fixed to be base and passed through the center of the isolation table and middle mass. The friction between the shaft and the isolation table and middle mass was reduced to the minimum possible level by using a suitable lubricant and ball bearings. Two additional threaded shafts and several hexagonal nuts were employed as stoppers and limiters for the movement of the isolation table and the middle mass. Two leaf springs were used to confine the rotational motions of the isolation table and middle mass. These leaf springs also behaved as dampers for both of the tables.

This research can be extended to develop a multi-degree-of-freedom vibration isolation system using multiple vibration isolation modules (Hoque et al., 2009). In such a system, six modules are used to control six-axis motions using parallel mechanism. However, actually it is difficult to realize the same characteristic for each of the modules. Therefore, the proposed control method is absolutely useful to adjust stiffness for each module.

sec.title: 6. Experimental results
sec.p:
A DSP-based digital controller (DS1103) was used for the implementation of the designed control algorithms by Simulink in Matlab. The sampling rate was 10 kHz. The experiments have been carried out to measure the performances both for the modified zero-power controller, as well as for the vibration isolation system. Figure 7 shows the load-displacement characteristics of the system with the modified zero-power controller (Figure 3). In this figure, the negative displacement is plotted against stepwise payload disturbances. When the proportional feedback gain, ps = 0, it can be considered as a conventional basic zero-power controller (Figure 2). The result shows that when the payloads were put on the suspended object, the isolation table moved in the direction opposite to the applied load, and the gap widened. This indicates that the zero-power control realized negative displacement, and hence its stiffness is negative. This validated the theoretical analysis presented by Equations (14) and (15). The conventional zero-power controller (ps=0) realized fixed negative stiffness of magnitude –9.2 N/mm. When the proportional feedback gain, ps was changed, the stiffness also gradually increased. When ps = 80 A/m, negative stiffness was increased to –103.1 N/mm. This confirms that the proportional feedback gain, ps can change the stiffness of the zero-power controller, as explained in Equation (15). Figure 7.
Load–displacement characteristics of the modified zero-power controller.

Figure 8 shows the power consumption characteristics of the modified zero-power controller. The control power necessary for the conventional zero-power controller (ps=0) was always zero. When the gain ps increased, a minor control power was necessary due to the steady power loss by the modified controller when static direct disturbance acted on the isolation table. It should be kept in mind that current offsets were included in the system by the passive weight support mechanism when the modified controller was used. In this case, the load of 5 N was canceled by the weight support mechanism so that it corresponds to F0=0. The zero-power characteristic point was shifted to approximately 5 N payload instead of F0=0. Detailed mathematical model about the reduction of steady-state force generated by the hybrid magnet by using the upward force of the weight support mechanism can be found in the analysis section of the reference presented by Mizuno et al. (2007b). Figure 8.
Power consumption against load by the modified zero-power controller.

Moreover, the maximum consumed power for ps = 80 A/m was approximately 0.37 W up to 10 N loads. However, the promising approach of this system is that the zero-power characteristic can be restored again by adjusting the weight support spring, once the system is stabilized. It is seen from Figure 8 that the zero-power characteristic can be found at 5 N payloads. However, this zero-power characteristic point can be shifted to 4 N or 6 N payloads by adjusting the stiffness of the passive weight support mechanism. It can be noted that the passive weight support mechanism cannot adjust negative stiffness of the system. In contrast, the modified zero-power control system can adjust negative stiffness sacrificing minor power. However, it can be replaced by adding a passive (conventional) spring in parallel with the hybrid magnet whose spring constant is equal to ki*ps. It enables the recovery of the zero-power characteristics.

The favorable point of the system is that it can realize zero power or low power if passive weight support mechanism and active modified zero-power control can be used together and when specific payload on the isolation table is known.

It is noteworthy that the modification of the controller is used to adjust the negative stiffness mainly for convenience in the experiment so that the steady power loss caused by the modification is not an essential problem.

Next, a comparative study has been conducted to measure the experimental and theoretical control currents as shown in Figure 9. A current offset of 0.4 A was included in the hybrid magnet by the weight support mechanism for the experiment. Therefore, the same current offset was also included in the theoretical results. In this case, the main physical parameters were experimentally identified as m = 8.12 kg, ki = 10.05 N/A, ks = 19616 N/m. Figure 9.
Comparative study of theoretical and experimental control currents for a gain of ps = 60 of the modified zero-power controller.

The theoretical results for ps = 60 A/m are approximately calculated from Equation (16). It can be noted that sign of the ps gain is negative in the Simulink model with a multiplication factor of 100. The gain of the amplifier was 1 A/V.

The experimental result shows that zero power was realized at a 5 N payload and maximum current was –0.5 A at 9.8 N payloads. The theoretical results are in agreement with the experimental results before 4 N payloads and the results deviated after a 4 N payload. This deviation might be due to the nonlinearity of the hybrid magnet. It is hoped that if control current is derived from a model including nonlinear compensation, better results can be obtained.

Finally, experiments have been carried out with the developed vibration isolation system. Zero-compliance characteristics of the isolation table to static direct disturbance using the modified zero-power controller is shown in Figure 10. In this case, stepwise static direct disturbance in the vertical direction of the isolation table was generated by putting payloads on the center of the isolation table. The displacements of the isolation tableto middle mass and that of the middle mass to the base were measured by eddy-current relative displacement sensors. It is seen from the figure that positive stiffness was realized between the base and the middle mass, and negative stiffness was realized between theisolation table and the middle mass. Zero compliance to direct disturbance of the isolation table was achieved when Equation (34) was satisfied. In other words, an infinite stiffness of the isolation system was realized that confirms Equation (35). At higher load (after 12 N in the figure), the zero-compliance characteristic may be lost due to the nonlinearity of the zero-power control system. A nonlinear compensation to zero-power controller can solve such problem (Hoque et al., 2006a). Figure 10.
Zero-compliance characteristics of the isolation table to static direct disturbance using the modified zero-power controller.

Figure 11 shows the frequency response of the isolation table to dynamic direct disturbance. In this experiment, the isolation table was excited by an electromagnet which was fixed to the base above the isolation table. The displacement of the isolation table was considered as the output in this case and the frequency response was measured by a dynamic signal analyzer. The result shows that the isolation table generated very low displacement at the low-frequency region. Displacement of the isolation table at 0.1 Hz was –122 dB [m/N]. It confirms that the isolation table generated very high stiffness at low-frequency dynamic direct disturbance. Figure 11.
Frequency response of the isolation table to dynamic direct disturbance.

Finally, the step response of the developed vibration isolation system was measured as shown in Figure 12. An electromagnet was employed to generate stepwise disturbance (0–10 N). The results demonstrate that the gap between the isolation table and the middle mass was increased and the displacement of the middle mass to base was decreased for downward disturbance on the isolation table. However, the isolation table returned to the original position within 0.6 s. The displacement and transient period to return to the original position can further be reduced by introducing feedforward control with the zero-power control system. The performance can further be improved by using higher closed-loop poles of the zero-power controller. Figure 12.
Step response of the isolation table.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: An improved control method for zero-power control has been proposed and successfully applied to a vibration isolation system. The zero-power control is modified by introducing a proportional displacement feedback to the zero-power controller. The modified zero-power controller generated negative stiffness with the capability to adjust negative stiffness. The concept was verified by some experiments. The experimental results showed that the stiffness of the magnetic suspension system depends on the proportional gains of the displacement feedback. The modified zero-power control had wide stiffness range and could be applied to develop a vibration isolation system. The system can further be improved by providing minor current feedback to the integral of the zero-power control system. Furthermore, a saturation element can also be added to the integrator of the minor current loop to switch the stiffness from negative to positive when excessive load is applied.

The infinite stiffness of the single-degree-of-freedom vibration isolation system has been realized when the absolute value of the negative stiffness was set to be equal to that of the mechanical springs. Therefore, the isolation system exhibited zero compliance to direct disturbance that acted on the isolation table. The static and dynamic response of the isolation table showed that the developed isolation system could effectively suppress the effect of direct disturbance. It can be noted that vibration suppression capability can further be improved by incorporating a feedforward controller with the zero-power control system.
